review:
I love the look and vibe of this game, which is a shame it seems to have been left to rot in the bowels of steam as it slowly becomes unplayable. My brief experience highlighted a dissapointing lack of basic features such as HUD size increasing, as text is so incredibly small that no amount of squinting could decipher what was going on. I couldn't tell if this had something to do with the built in resolution or the fact that I was on a 4k monitor or what, but even though the game has these resolutions as options it clearly wasn't designed around them. 

This is a shame as it seems the entire game is effected by this bizarre scaling issue, including the opening cinematic. However even after lowering the resolution repeatedly I still could never get it to a size that seemed at least functional--very bizarre. 

On a stylistic level I love everything about this game, and the music has a wonderful bop to it that matches the energy of the artstyle. Unfortunately, that's about all I can say on the matter as of now as I cannot complete the tutorial do to the perspective bug I've mentioned--but if I am ever able to get this game to run properly I will give it a more fair review. 

However, let this be a cautionary review for anyone who stumbles across this game in the modern year.

review:
It's a great indie game. Unlocking the additional characters give new ways to play levels. The controls are tight enough to pull things off, however I did at times get a bit frustrated with not nailing the exact spot to stay out of line of sight. The guards patrols are completely random at all times and every reset of playing a level will position them in different spots etc, but playing through the game (without trying to do perfect runs) was decent fun. 

However I can't imagine the amount of grind time and huge frustration that would go into trying to beat the par time on each level just due to the random way guards patrol and the fact you have absolutely no clue which way they'll turn at any point. The amount of times you get painted into a corner in later levels (with timed lasers etc) and the guards seemingly always manage to choose your direction out of nowhere... good luck with that (for those hardcore achievement hunters).

review:
Played it with an X-box controller. This is quite a solid and challenging stealth game. What it does good is reward patience, but also quick actions that need to be perfectly timed. Once I accepted I would fail a few times on a floor before I got it right, I enjoyed it a lot more. As you really learn and figure out what to do, and what to avoid.

There are some cons though, but these are mostly related to the interface and the progression:
- For the progression in the main Level choosing interface two systems were used, (1) An empty space on the wall is an unfinished level / achievement, a frame on the wall is a finished level. (2) An empty frame on the wall is an unfinished level / achievement, a frame on the wall is a finished level. This could have been more consistent overall.
- When playing the later levels in the game, there are multiple floors, but it is unkown how many there are. So I found it very frustrating, that I could enjoy the win on a floor only for 1 second. As I noticed yet another floor appeared. Would have been nice to see how many floors there were still to go, to get a sense of how far along you are in one of the later levels.
- The faster paced timing challenges do very often feel more like luck than skill.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201620245', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 608, 'playtime_forever': 465, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 465, 'last_played': 1636786758}
review:
First thing first, the GUI is beyond incompetent.
Good luck understanding what menu entry you are about to click on with a gamepad, quitting when you want to quit, staying when you don't want to quit, getting back to full screen view after an Alt Tab...
Enjoy traversing your entire manor back to wherever you were supposed to be every time you cancel a mission.

The killer combination tough... that would be the randomness of patrols with the poor level design and the lack of balls of the developer.
The randomness is such that it transforms every heist in a dice game.
The level design cramps too many goals into too small spaces with a lot of random patrols.
That makes the RNG go exponential.
And it would still be enjoyable if the developer had the courage to let the players save.
But they were scared it would make their product shorter.
They couldn't compute that giving up on a game makes it shorter than finishing it, on top of disorienting a thumb.

One heist takes a long time, stealth games being games of patience, long minutes multiplied by the number of attempts.
Yet here, missions are chained without saving; inter-missions checkpoints are valid for the current session only.
This stupid design creates the same stupid issue it does in many stupid games: You need hours of guaranteed free time ahead of you before launching this disappointware.
Personally, when I do have time for a long session, I don't launch a casual game but an involving one.

Meanwhile, the straw that broke my camel toe is different entirely.
We revisit the same galleries with 3 characters, each thief having a different ability.
Until the story went and removed the only character I actually enjoyed playing.
That was petty.
Now I sulk.

review:
A stealth game with a lot of heart, Miss Take offers a challenging but very engaging experience. This is one of those games that were unfairly overlooked back in the day. The first stages of the game are a bit deceptive, it seems too simple. After the first act, however, things start getting more interesting and challenging. New characters will be available, each one with their own features and challenges. The art design is quite charming and the OST deserves high praise because the different melodies are absolutely astonishing. Speaking of this, there are certain moments of suspense whe the music volume is lowered until you overcome that situation. Then, an explosion of jazzy tunes come roaring back again. These little touches really make the game shine.

The story is simple but the message it conveys is something I want to highlight. Art must be held in public museums where everybody could enjoy it, it should not be in the hands of private collectors.

*One important aspect to consider is that despite the fact the game can be played with a mouse, the framerate can get messy quite often. There is an easy workaround, playing with a controller offers a more stable framerate which is better suited in a stealth game.

review:
I want to love this game. It's got a delightful quirkiness to it - plot, characters, art style, all are charming. But the game play is abysmal.

It's almost not. It's almost perfect. If they'd just given the guards patrol patterns it would be amazing. But instead the guards are completely random. They will wander anywhere and everywhere, they will turn around without any warning at any time. They transform the game from a fun skilful romp to completely chance based luck-a-paloza. The game tries to give you options to influence them, but they're few, and mostly ineffective. It's hard to enjoy yourself when you're stuck behind a small piece of cover for 20 minutes waiting for the guard to stop randomly walking backwards and forwards in your escape route (but don't worry, eventually they'll catch sight of a sliver of you that has been completely hidden every other time they've looked your way and end your run regardless).

I want to love this game. It's such a disappointment to find it so frustrating.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045119638', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 774, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 774, 'last_played': 1614960526}
review:
Not that I'm the best at reviews but here goes:

A quick TL:DR summary
Story: There is one
Controls: Simple yet fun
Gameplay: Standard stealth with a twist
Style: A+ very sleek
Music: Pleasant elevator style
Difficulty: Keyboard smashingly hard
Overall: Love it, great game.

I saw Jacksepticeye play this one time and the style and swagger of the game told me one thing; I must have it! So I bought it and expected a few hours of casual fun, boy was I wrong.
   
Now before we get to that, the game is great. Thes story is nothing great but gets the job done. The marvelous Miss Take has you take (no pun intended) the role of Sophia Take whos aunt dies and leaves a massive art collection for her. However she is cheated out of her inheritance and as a result makes the decision to steal all the art back. You subsequently have to guide Sophia or one of her two partners in crime through a series of levels, stealing everything in sight while dodging guards and ducking cameras.
   
The gameplay is easy to learn, use the mouse to move Sophia and... that's it. You use the mouse for everything, be it walking, running, distracting, using gadgets etc. which makes the game simplistic in that nice way. Using your trusted mouse you will steal various art peices while going through pretty standard stealth gameplay, hide, distract, learn patterns and such but with a slight twist: the guards move randomly. Cameras and lasers follow patterns but guards will simply saunter around the level at random which encourages (hrm, forces) you to distract them in order to work around them. A nice if bothersome addition as you have to put all of that Assassins creed thinking out of your head but still
  
As for the feel of the game: awsome. As I said the style of this game is astonishing. (It was one of the main things that made me want this game) and the levels and menu screens blend beautifully with eachother, add to that some suave music and we are set for greatness.
   
Now as I said before: casual fun this game is not. The tag is mighty misleading as the game is really difficult. The first few levels are easily completed and you feel confident going into chapter 2 where the difficulty ramps up with the pay-to-win speed of a mobile game. The guards are plentiful and their sightcone is enormous (easily covers an entire room) on top of which you have to time lasers and cameras while also dealing with dogs that sniff you out (*Last of us 2 flashbacks*) all in the confides of a tiny room. As if that wasn't bad enough the random patterns of the guards means that it is basically impossible to form any type of plan, forcing you to think on your feet. Trust me, you will be angry, you will yell things like: "oh come on I was right there" or "Ofcourse he turned around right then" and you will be forced to try every level again, and again... and again (and that's not even mentioning the bonus time objectives). Luckily, much like Cuphead, the levels are only about 2 minutes long so where as you will be forced to redo them, it won't be a slog. 
P.S. pro tip: Resist the urge to run when the brown stuff hits the fan, you'll thank me later.

To sum it all up: I love this game. With it's sleek visuals, chill music and fun gameplay it makes for a great experience. Yes it is difficult and yes at times unfair but despite that I kept coming back and I finished it and I don't regret a thing. And coming from a guy who usually gives up when games get hard, I'd say that accounts for something. And even if difficulty isn't your thing: those first few levels are fun.

review:
I keep coming back to this game. It can be incredibly frustrating at times, but that's all in the fun when playing in the mindset of Miss Take, a Carmen Sandiego-esque art thief who strolls through a gallery with ease and class. This game is in my opinion endlessly replayable, as the position and movement of the guards is randomised each time you enter a level, which can either work in your favour or make you wish you weren't caught red handed with the gallery's masterpiece when having to navigate three guards and one guard dog all in a small room. 

The mechanics of this game are simple, move through the space, picking up art as you go, try not to make too much noise or stand in vision of the guards unless you have a devious distraction to deploy. The soundtrack is beautiful and really transports you into the world of the game. And the main story of the game is just the beginning as you unlock two other playable characters with their own quirks and abilities that maker you approach the levels in interesting new ways. This game doesn't punish you for being caught too many times, which means it remains fun throughout as you repeat a gallery heist for the fifth time, trying to get all of the collectables in the fastest time. Looks and runs beautifully, would highly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11207, 'playtime_forever': 414, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 414, 'last_played': 1579104885}
review:
The Marvellous Miss Take is a stealth game where you steal works of art from various simple 2D levels (with 3D graphics), avoiding guards and whistling to distract them.   Timing and randomness are the key challenges here. 

The game works well in 4K and while the graphics are simplistic, they're tastefully done.   The key problem here is that this is very much a tablet tier game, yet the developers have released it on Steam rather than mobile.   They're charging $28.95 for a tablet equivalent game on PC, when they probably know full well that if they released it on tablet it would be a $2 game.   Even though the game works, it's totally not worth AAA pricing that they've set.   I can't understand their reasoning, nor can I recommend the game based on the unrealistic pricing here for what's at best middle tier bundleware.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998920982', 'num_games_owned': 255, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 548, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 64, 'last_played': 1610314761}
review:
A chaotic stealth game where guards are random and unpredictable. In theory this means the player must think and react quickly, but getting caught immediately results in a loss, which forces the player to restart and hope the guard positions are more favorable next time.  While most levels are relatively short and provide checkpoints, the repeated restarts can be time-consuming.  Overall not terrible, but not good enough to recommend.
Pros:
+ Levels have some replay value because there are multiple characters with distinct stealth mechanics.
Cons:
- The randomized guard behavior makes success seem luck-dependent, and leaves little room for strategy or planning in advance. Being forced to repeatedly restart a level can quickly become frustrating. 
- Character movement is imprecise because multiple different controls (walk, run, open, move camera, etc) are mapped to the same context-based click input.
- The fixed isometric camera can make movement unreliable when trying to navigate behind objects or walls, and the inability to zoom out often means getting caught by off-screen guards.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995123512', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 631, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 626, 'last_played': 1575473176}

author: {'steamid': '76561198024984271', 'num_games_owned': 347, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 109, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 110, 'last_played': 1574050315}
review:
Yeah it was fun at first.  Chapter One is fine, but the second section of Chapter Two really just won't let me get past it. No matter what path I take, no matter how careful I am, I am always caught. I'm actually starting to wonder if it is possible to get past it at all. 

The UI isn't at all helpful. You can click on a spot you want Miss Take to move to and instead of going directly there she will move slightly past it and sometimes a little around a corner of the display table into the path of a camera or guard. Also if you happen to leave your finger on the mouse button for more than a micro fraction of a second Miss Take will  run which will of course alerts the guard. 

Whistling to attract the guards just makes it easier for them to catch you. Add to this there seems to be a problem with the guards where they just will not leave the room if you are in it. If you are outside the room, they will wander into the room and then leave, but once you are in some rooms, they just stick around and won't go away. Which would be fine, if it was just one guard. But two guards and a camera means no way out which forces you to fail. 

Some of the time if you're in a certain position on screen, you can't move the camera up or down far enough to check out where the nearby guards are either. And the teleport device has a super long cool down. Someone mentioned in another comment that the cooldown is dependant on the treasure you have, but really its just annoying and makes you sit in a corner waiting and waiting until you can use it again. 

The game really needs some balance and improvements but as an older game I don't see this happening.

review:
Яскравий ізометричний стелс-екшн з простою історією та милозвучною музикою. В грі приємна графіка і непоганий дизайн, але все ж таки, з часом набридає проходити схожі між собою рівні. Зіграти можна за трьох різних персонажів, у кожного з яких власний стиль гри та гаджети, що дозволяє трішки урізноманітнити проходження. Гра не складна і легко розібратися що й до чого, але саме керування персонажем за допомогою мишки і клавіатури залишає бажати кращого, тому над деякими рівнями прийдеться попітніти ;) Головним недоліком гри є хаотичний рух охоронців: з однієї сторони цікаво, що не має лінійних маршрутів, котрі легко прорахувати і проскочити повз, але з іншої сторони - їхня поведінка це повний рандом, вони можуть збитися в кучу і оточити вашого персонажа намертво, або ж залишити без нагляду майже весь рівень.
Якщо ви думаєте чи придбати цю гру, то раджу робити це при знижці -80% і більше, або ж у якомусь бандлі.
Добре, що є досягнення (середньої складності) і колекційні картки (3/6).
Оцінюю її на 7 з 10!

review:
Okay so, for the first 3 chapters this is a pretty decent top down stealth game. Then chapter 4 unlocks and you get the utterly irritating and shit laser triggered alarms, this is in addition to guards, cameras and dogs. Basically it becomes a complete and utter shitfest. What's worse is that in addition to just jamming a whole lot of crap that can detect you into small rooms, the guard pathing is completely randomized, so you can't learn their paths you just have to go with the flow. You end up with a very frustrating and RNG driven experience. It's not difficult in a good way, the levels aren't intelligently designed, it's only difficult because of RNG and a ridiculous amount of shit that can detect you and because the tools you have at your disposal to distract guards are inadequate.

Don't buy this even on a discount, it's trash, there are much better alternatives out there. One game that immidiately comes to mind is Volume. It's another top down stealth game but unlike this one it's actually good. You see, Volume understands what makes good challenge and difficulty, good games treat failure as a lesson. With Volume you can learn from your mistakes, improve and do better. This trash game punishes you because "yay, RNG" and no other reason.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103941003', 'num_games_owned': 321, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1156, 'last_played': 1448042278}
review:
I’m going to be honest: I’m not a huge fan of stealth elements in video games.  I find them frustrating to play through, since most games do not provide you with cues regarding whether the NPCs can see or hear you until it’s far too late.  So I was very concerned when I started to play [i]The Marvelous Miss Take[/i] (a game I obtained through a Humble Bundle), fearing it would play like yet another tacked on stealth segment found in so many modern action games.  Instead I discovered that playing this game was not a mistake; quite the opposite in fact.

[i]The Marvelous Miss Take[/i] is the real deal; stealth, spatial awareness, and tricking your enemies by going into and out of their fields of vision, or making noise, is crucial to completely each level of this game.  And even better still, each player character in the game has their own unique play styles, meaning that you actually have to take into account each character’s unique abilities.  This is especially noticeable when playing as Harry Carter, one of the few examples of a physically disabled player character in a video game.  Instead of focusing on getting through each level swiftly, his major objectives to getting a perfect score is to get past each level unseen by both the security guards and the cameras, meaning pattern memorization and creating distractions by making noise with his cane and personal gadgets, are your keys to success.

Add a catchy, yet relaxing, soundtrack, bright colourful visuals with stylized character designs that pop and get your attention make [i]The Marvelous Miss Take[/i] an excellent game to play regardless of your previous (dis)interest in the stealth genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077964931', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 165, 'last_played': 1511989923}
review:
So I think The Marvelous Miss Take is a pretty slick stealth game but I would also like buyers to be aware of how the random guard patterns is not always a bonus. Yes, the randomness encourages you to be aware of your surroundings, but you probably were already. I feel like the main problem this randomness has is that it eliminates the puzzle-like aspect of most stealth games, where you have to map your way around obstacles without being spotted. Some of my favorite moments of this game come from finding ways to consistently dodge around early obstacles, attempting to beat the time limit. But this game hardly allows you to do that, because you never know exactly where the guards might be or where they're looking, making a lot of the speed strats simply to pray to RNGesus. 
That's not to say the game is all luck, it isn't, but I still can't help but feeling I'm still the same player I was when I first started playing. I say this because even though I've completed more than half the levels, I would still be just as challenged to try and complete them again. That's my gripe with this game. The RNG elements rob you of some of your sense of accomplishment with the knowledge that anything you just did will be just as hard the next time, reassuring you that you haven't improved in the slightest.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991465987', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 278, 'playtime_forever': 897, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 897, 'last_played': 1511471914}
review:
The Marvellous Miss Take starts out as a wonderful game - tasteful visuals, great music and sound design, and slick, light-hearted gameplay. It was a nice casual stealth experience until Episode 3, where things got more serious(ly annoying), and then the last two episodes where pretty much a meltdown. I rarely feel like this, but I specifically regret the time spent on Episode 5 :(
I guess it's obvious from the above that the game stopped to be fun when the difficulty increased. It can of course mean that a) I s*ck at stealth games, but it can also mean that b) the game's mechanics are not good enough for more complicated scenarios. Unsurprisingly, I vote b). Some of my reasons:
- The environments are too small, there's hardly any room for maneuvering. This destroys most Daisy scenarios, unless you're of the goatherder persuasion. Especially if you want to work in full stealth, which would be my first choice.
- Controls are not accurate. That's not a problem early in the game until you don't have to round corners with a laser field right at your legs.
- Random guard movements. It's super fun early on, and super annoying when the game gets tough. You basically need to finish the late levels as if the computer was generating random numbers specifically to hamper you. I'm not saying the game is cheating, mind you - but it certainly feels so at times, especially in Episode 5.

There's more, but I don't want to dissect the game any further, and I'm giving it a (very reluctant) thumbs up anyway. The first two episodes were a blast, 3 and 4 were increasingly annyoing but bearable, so it's still a lot of worthy content. Just make sure you have nerves of steel for Ep5, or forget it altogether.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986360343', 'num_games_owned': 1568, 'num_reviews': 866, 'playtime_forever': 733, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 661, 'last_played': 1510487110}
review:
Giving someone who's a thief the surname "take" is an excellent choice. Meet Sophia, who only wishes to steal back what is rightfully hers. Along the way she meets Harry and Daisy; the 3 of them team up to find out what happened to Sophia's will (after the passing away of a close family member) and, of course, to steal a lot of paintings and other stuff from art galleries. 

The "home" section shows your own gallery where you can launch a level. Each level has 2 floors to be completed. You can only control one character at a time: when Harry and later Daisy join you notice the already completed levels can be done by them, too. Naturally, this means a rather different positioning of guards as each character has a different playstyle.

With Sophia we steal most items. A lot of objects and paintings and each level has one object behind a window case. As the heist occurs during opening hours there are civilians in the galleries. They only notify guards when you smash this one particular window case. Your best bet is to immediately hide. Generally speaking, your job is to try to avoid the line of sight of guards, cameras and dogs. Later on wall-mounted lasers make your job more difficult. Sophia is a must for story progression - Harry and Daisy can only enter a level if it has already been completed by their friend.

With Harry running is not an option anymore as he walks with the use of a cane. He enters the galleries at night time and with him we need to steal fewer paintings only. In my opinion Harry's playthrough is the most difficult in the absence of running. If you run with Sophia or Daisy it can be heard if guards are close-by but in a distance it is an extremely useful feature. Back to Harry: he can drop a ball to emit noise and distract guards. You need to make sure you pick it up before leaving a level.

With Daisy I found the game the most exciting. Our job is to get close to each guard to steal a key so that a safe can be opened. Every opening triggers the alarm so make sure you have a plan for escaping as the guards will definitely check the area. While running Daisy emits a sound in a much smaller radius than Sophia.

Overall we have 25 levels to complete (beside the tutorial), so that's 75 times the fun considering the 3 protagonists. The game has great music; each level has a name of a street found in England. The graphics and the accompanying music indicate this must be the 1950s or 60s. Sometimes civilians comment on the thefts that all appear on the news; we can always read the latest headlines in newspapers between each stage.

The downside of Miss Take is that it has an uneven difficulty. The A.I. controlling the guards often gives them different commands. We can find it difficult to steal only one particular painting in a heavily guarded room. After a couple of attempts we notice even the other rooms are a bit more difficult to complete as you never know where a guard will be moving. This is especially true when it comes to starting a level: if they move to the opposite direction we know we are off to a good start.

Miss Take is a great stealth-based adventure game with a unique atmosphere. If you like challenges you can try beating all part times with Sophia and Daisy for extra achievements. With Harry, as he cannot run, the extra difficulty lies in not being noticed, at all, i.e. "ghosting" each level. I hardly play more than 10 hours with an indie game but Miss Take was worth every minute of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131701503', 'num_games_owned': 242, 'num_reviews': 156, 'playtime_forever': 1012, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1012, 'last_played': 1502964614}
review:
[b]The Marvellous Miss Take[/b] is a game I liked enough to 100%, and on that basis I feel obligated to recommend it, but that must come with a list of caveats.  There are three major, and a few minor, problems I had that prospective buyer should beware.

First, the controls are not very good.  The default mouse controls are just awful; they don't offer the level of control needed to respond to changing situations.  Thankfully, you can switch to WASD keyboard controls, which have three problems.  First, they felt stiff and unresponsive; the number of times I failed after accidentally tripping a laser is too many.  Second, far, [i]far[/i] too often I'd get stuck on the edge of furniture or doorframes.  Lastly, you still have to use the mouse to interact with things.  Which wouldn't be a problem, but you do this so rarely I found it more comfortable to use my off hand for the run command (Shift), and then had to scramble to reach the mouse when needed.  You also use the mouse to throw things, which is not convenient for quick responses either.

Second, the guard movements are random.  Which generally wouldn't be a problem except for the optional time challenges.  In my opinion, too many of those can only be beaten with luck.  It gets very annoying when you repeatedly start a level, then quit two seconds in as a guard you need to lure is looking the wrong way.  Even worse is when you get most of the way through and then get caught when a guard off-screen happens to look at you or wander in range of a safe alarm.  That randomness also means that the difficulty curve is all over the place; even late in the game levels can become trivial with just a little good fortune.

Third is that you need to press escape then make two mouse clicks to restart a level, for no reason that I can see.  That might not seem like much, but given how often I restarted levels, it really got on my nerves.  One click on 'Restart' should be enough to restart!

The game would also benefit from the ability to rotate the camera.  Perhaps that's asking too much of an indie game, but there where a few occasions when I couldn't see clearly thanks to my character being blocked by a wall, that interfered with my play.

Given all these problems, what kept me playing the game?  The basic gameplay is solid.  There are clear visibility and awareness cones for everything, so except for off-screen guards it's clear where's safe and where's not.  Once you understand how to lure the guards away from what they are guarding, the puzzles become the fun sort of challenging.  The different gameplay styles of the three PCs also add another dimension to each level.  The main character also gets to use a variety of different items as they progress through the game, which helps to keep things varied; it's just a shame something similar couldn't have been done for the other two PCs.

Also, I really like the game's art design.  It's simple but elegant and fits the mood quite well.

There's a lot of fun to be had from [b]The Marvellous Miss Take[/b], but also a lot of frustration.  I'd recommend it if you like stealth games and puzzle games, and like a modest challenge.

review:
Purchasing this game was no 'Miss Take.'

A fairly simple stealth based art thievery game with a nice little art style and basic one button control scheme completely via the mouse. Great pick up and put down style of game where you play a few levels and take a break for a bit.

Only a few minor issues with the game, primarily the inconsistancy of difficulty; especially between the characters. Sophia is average difficulty while Harry, the first unlocked character, has far easier stages. Later Daisy is unlocked and her levels can be frustrating beyond belief.

Guards do not follow any set patrols and force you to constantly improvise your way through a level. This is both a good thing and a bad one. Sometimes guards will decide to just constantly cockblock your objective with no real way to distract them without failing the stage.

Good little game barring the few things holding it back from true greatness. If you want a nice little casual stealth game you can't really go wrong here.

review: A stealth game with random guards. Sounds hard, right? Well, you're not exactly wrong. In The Marvellous Miss Take, you have to use all method at your disposal to distract the guards. author: {'steamid': '76561198083550415', 'num_games_owned': 13258, 'num_reviews': 192, 'playtime_forever': 122, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 122, 'last_played': 1488891991}
review:
The Marvellous Miss Take привлекла мое внимание скриншотами, на которых игра выглядела как неплохой стелс-экшн про грабежи с оригинальным стилем. Но к сожалению, за яркой оберткой не оказалось интересного игрового процесса.

Игра создавалась с прицелом на Android/iOS девайсы с сенсорным экраном, и это хорошо заметно с самого начала. Управлению катастрофически не хватает точности и отзывчивости, подконтрольный персонаж постоянно норовит выйти из укрытия и влезть в поле зрение охраны. Чтобы прокрасться куда-то нужно один раз нажать левой кнопкой мышки по нужному месту, а чтобы перейти на бег требуется два нажатия, и это провоцирует кучу ситуаций, когда при попытке чередования перебежек от укрытия к укрытию персонаж делает не то что от него требуется и заваливает всю миссию. Особенно это раздражает когда приходится убегать от охраны, где чередование бега и скрытного перемещения очень важно, так как иначе охранник все равно услышит ваш топот и поймает героя. С гаджетами, которые можно найти на некоторых уровнях, та же проблема - выцеливать нужную траекторию для броска с помощью зажатой правой кнопки мышки нормально можно только если стоять на месте, и то не факт, что гаджет не отлетит по странной траекторией обратно к вам, зацепившись за невидимый угол.

Ладно бы только управление, но ведь разработчики допустили самую фатальную ошибку - абсолютно рандомное перемещение охраны по уровню. Нет, в самом рандоме нет ничего плохого, при правильной реализации это только увеличивает интерес к игре. Но в The Marvellous Miss Take рандом означает именно что полный рандом - куда пойдет охранник дальше предугадать невозможно, никакого шаблона, за которым можно проследить и воспользоваться, нет в принципе. Как-то поднять камеру и полностью оценить ситуацию на уровне целиком тоже нельзя, осматривать можно только кусок этажа в небольшом радиусе от подконтрольного персонажа. Чаще всего уровни проходятся не из-за четкого плана и холодного расчета, а просто из-за того, что конкретно в этот раз вам повезло и все охранник увлеченно рассматривали стены или зашли в какой-то дальний угол карты. Уже спустя час игра вызывала только непреодолимое чувство уныния и фрустрации, потому что ничто так не раздражает в тактической игре, как невозможность спланировать свои действия.

Словно этого мало, The Marvellous Miss Take очень быстро становится однообразной и даже заставляет перепроходить старые уровни, только другими персонажами и с небольшими косметическими отличиями. Уровни созданы из очень ограниченного набора кусочков и не предлагают каких-то по-настоящему других ситуаций, новые гаджеты и типы охраны кардинально не меняют однообразной сути игры. Неудивительно, что, судя по достижениям, The Marvellous Miss Take прошли всего 3% (!) игроков, я сам выдержал 2 часа исключительно из-за того, что ждал выпадения карточек. На выходе имеем внешне красивую, но очень однообразную игру с плохим управлением и отсутствием возможности четко спланировать свои действия, что для тактической игры смерти подобно. Если душа желает стильного и умного стелса в изометрии, то лучше сыграйте в Invisible, Inc, чем в эту сомнительную аркаду с мобилок.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990558953', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 181, 'last_played': 1424538518}
review:
Sophia Take skulle arve en fantastisk kunstsamling. I stedet blev hun snydt så vandet driver, og nu er de kostbare billeder og skulpturer spredt ud over hele London. Men Sophia er fast besluttet på at få sine kunstværker igen. Så du må styre Sophia gennem kunstgallerierne, så hun kan komme uset forbi overvågningskameraer og vagter, indtil hun kan stjæle kunstværkerne tilbage. The Marvellous Miss Take er et rigtigt snige-spil, hvor der ikke er meget at gøre, hvis Sophia bliver opdaget. Heldigvis kan hun bruge en masse udstyr til at distrahere de ikke alt for snedige vagter og lave det perfekte kup. Den seje Sophia ligner Disneys Kim Possible, og hele stemningen er ret cool. Det passer godt til et spil, hvor det gælder om at være listig og hurtig, og man ikke kan løse problemerne med vold.
Sophia møder et par andre tyve, der har hver deres speciale og særlige evner. Det forlænger spillets levetid, for du kan vende tilbage til et galleri, som du har ”befriet” for kunstværker og løse nye udfordringer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116939136', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 1161, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1100, 'last_played': 1479982025}
review:
[h1]A solid 11 oceans out of 10 art heists[/h1]

This review is a reupload from [url=https://gaolioccasionallyreviews.wordpress.com/2016/10/24/the-marvellous-miss-take/]Gao Li Occasionally Reviews[/url]

[i]The Marvellous Miss Take[/i] (Wonderstruck, 2014) is a short, but incredibly fun to play and beautiful to look at stealth game. The art collection Miss Sophia Take was supposed to inherit from her aunt was stolen by Ralph Blackstock and she and her friends have not just vowed to reclaim it, but also uncover the truth behind his ill-gotten gains. In this game with an isometric camera angle, players engage in various art heists in 25 different galleries (not counting tutorial and epilogues) as one of three characters: Sophia Take, the master thief Harry Carver, or the pick pocket Daisy Hobbs.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=785268579

[h1]Controls[/h1]

[i]Miss Take[/i] can be played either with your keyboard/mouse combo or a controller. For this review, I used a wired Xbox 360 joypad by Microsoft that the game only recognized the first time I plugged it in. After that, whenever I started the game, I had to navigate to the 《Settings》menu and then to 《Controls》, click on 《Keyboard Movement》and could only then use the gamepad. Sometimes I even had to do that twice. This was definitely not the fault of my toaster [spoiler] (a 32-bit Windows Vista computer with 3070MB RAM, Intel Core 2 CPU, GeForce 9500 GT, and DX11)[/spoiler] as it also happened on a Lenovo G50-80E5 laptop [spoiler](64-bit, with Windows 10, 8GB RAM, Intel Core i7 CPU, Intel HD Graphics 5500, DX11)[/spoiler].

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Each location can be played through using all three of the protagonists, all of whom have their separate tasks at hand and differing handicaps: Sophia’s missions are the easiest, despite her having the loudest footsteps and having to steal the most amount of art – during opening hours nonetheless. Harry – having to take three painting from each floor without being seen by any of the guards – cannot run and breaks in during night time. Finally, there’s Daisy whom the guards only notice when she is in their direct field of view. She breaks in during closing days, stealing the keys from the guards and then taking the contents from Blackstock’s safe-deposit boxes. To add spice to the game, the levels are timed while the movement patterns of non-player characters are randomized. Although this might be a nightmare scenario for speedrunners, it turns out to be a fun affair with high replay value for semi-casual players like myself. 

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=785268410

There certainly was a lot of love and skill put into the game. The soundtrack is amazing and the cel shaded characters and environments give the whole adventure the more than welcome comic look. Not just that, but the awesomely looking, interactive startup screen changes with each reclaimed painting. Unfortunately, this means that [i]The Marvellous Miss Take[/i] only has one save slot, making it impossible to share it with your sibling or significant other. Nevertheless, erasing the save can be done from inside the game, which is nice.

The gameplay mechanics are few, thus easy to remember, and well explained. Dangers, like the field of view of the guards, are exquisitely indicated. An issue might be, sadly, that one rather often has to restart stages as the protagonists can end up cornered by the random movement patterns of the guards. Luckily enough, all of the stages are very brief and can all be beaten in less than five minutes, several can take even less than two minutes, if you know what you are doing. Sadly, the plot and the characters are very rudimentary and feel unfinished, so if you are a fan of story-rich games, this might not be your title.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=785268497

[h1]Play length[/h1]

Overall it took me around 14 hours to beat the game and an additional two hours (16 hours total gameplay) to get all achievements. After beating the par-time for all stages, players can try to beat the pro-, and afterwards the developer-times, the latter I haven’t unlocked as of writing this article (19 hours of total gameplay).

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

[i]The Marvellous Miss Take[/i] comes highly recommended; there even is a free demo version available, if you want to try it out before purchasing. The problem I had with the controller is a minor one, once I learned what to do. The title’s brevity and moderate difficulty make it perfect for the gamer who does not have that much time any longer, but would like to engage in a few adventures from time to time. The randomized movement patterns and par-, pro-, and dev- time limits also make it fun for those that like a bit of challenge.

author: {'steamid': '76561198142920541', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 102, 'last_played': 1471988242}
review:
This game is fine if you like hard things. I mean, really hard things. About Super Meat Boy-level hardness but in a stealth game, and everything is random. Well, not everything. Just the guard patterns (and that includes dogs as well). 

The first chapter was fun. The style is fantastic. I liked it--simple control scheme, basic objective, silly story. That was good. In the first chapter, the guard patterns can be irritating but not over-the-top rage-quitting. The guards have 4 stages of awareness of you--... awareness, which is just "Is there something there?". That fills up fast, and then you get ? awareness, which is where they come looking. Once ? fills up, you get !, which is where they run after you. If you can escape them and hide, they will have a red ? bar which will go down. If they see you during that time, it immediately goes back to !.

But once you get into the second chapter, there are guard dogs. 

Guard dogs have a gigantic scent radius all around them and a small sight radius in front of them. As soon as you touch the sight radius their question-mark bar starts going up fast. They can't catch you like regular guards, but they will bark, which draws guards. If you walk in the scent-radius, they will start following your footsteps. The only way to get rid of them on your trail is to "run away". Apparently this means just going really far away from them, but it's not clear about that, and running makes noise. The guard dogs have a low tolerance to noise. If they hear you running, they will fill up about a third of their ? bar. This makes it extremely difficult to actually get past them, especially if there's a security camera in the room. Then it's awful.

All in all, if you like very hard games, fine. If not, I would recommend getting it heavily on sale or in a bundle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034974555', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 82, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 82, 'last_played': 1471364244}
review:
IS THIS GAME ANY GOOD?

It's a simple stealth game, though simple does not equal easy.
one thing that makes thig game unique from other stealth games is that the guards from whom you have to hide from walk randomly meaning that they don't have a pattern, this of course adds a sense of suspence and surprise to the game as you're forced to make up your plan as you go, there's just no other option, because of this no two gameplays will be the same.
Many people in their review will complain about the random guard movements but that's what whistling or other gadgets are for in the game.
Whistling attracts a guard's attention and will make them go towards the noise, this means that although in general the guard's movements are random this is NOT a game of pure luck, you just need to know when to whistle and where, if you master that then you will be able to enjoy the game.
The story is simple and the two main characters are interesting each with unique features that change the way you play the game depending on who you pick.
The graphics are simple but that plays to its advantage as it has a nice comic book feel to it and of course because of that it's easy on the graphics cards which means that most if not all can buy and enjoy this game without stupid fps drop issues.
My only nitpick if I'd have to pick something here it would be the music.
It's pleasant however I do see it getting old after a while (but that's not a big deal considering you can just switch the music off and put your own music from your pc as the bgm)

And finally the overall satisfaction of the game... is good.
Sure, it's not a triple A title but there again it never advertised itself as some sort of jesus of games and it fully delivers what it promises.

I rate this game 8/10
I gave this game an 8/10 because although it is a very fun game to play, it is a shame that the developers did not add a level editor which would increase this game's replayability.

Well done minimal-controls stealth game with a bit of emergent gameplay and adorable graphics/sounds. I don't know if I'd recommend it for the full price of €18, but it has been discounted often enough, and for €4.5 (Current 75% discount.) or even more you can't go wrong with this one. It's a nice package of fun that you can play in short sessions every now and then.

The levels have two floors, and while you always start at the beginning of the last floor you failed at, the game only saves once a mission is completed, so don't quit before the level is completed and you're back at the mansion. (In that regard, it reminds of Hotline Miami which behaved just like this.)

It's a firm [b]thumbs-up[/b] when discounted.

review:
2Dベースのカジュアルステルスアクション

ストーリーは、叔母から相続するはずだった沢山の絵画や美術品をRalphに奪われたミス・テイクが、Ralphの美術館に盗みに入ってそれらを取り戻していくというもの
ステルスなので敵に見つからずに盗み脱出できれば成功となります
カジュアルな部分といえば、敵の動きが基本ランダムなため、見つかるなどして移動させてもほとんどの場合元の場所に帰らないこと
つまり敵の防衛網を突破する戦略を考えるというよりは、とりあえず行動して敵をおびき出せればなんとかなります
ステージによっては煙幕など強力なアイテムが使えて繰り返しの作業にならない工夫が見えます

一番いいと思った点はグラフィックやアニメーションで、グラフィックは紹介から期待される通りです
ミス・テイクのミッション完了時のどやポーズは思わずスクショを撮りたくなるでしょう
他にも敵に捕まったときのヤレヤレといった感じのポーズや、アラームを鳴らしてしまったときの慌て具合などが可愛らしくて好感が持てました

グラフィックやゲーム性に期待が持てるならプレイして損はないでしょう

review: The Marvellous Miss Take m'a agréablement surpris. Habitué des jeux d'infiltration où nous sommes obligés de nous cacher et laisser passer les ennemis dans un style plutôt sombre, ce jeu n'a absolument rien à voir. Ici tout est coloré, sans violence, et les déplacements des gardes et autres personnages sont complètement aléatoires. Du coup, vous devrez trouver à chaque fois un chemin différent en utilisant les gadgets plutôt variés des 3 protagonistes. Le jeu se compose de 25 niveaux découpés en 2 parties dont l'objectif change en fonction du personnage joué, ce qui nous fait quand même 75 niveaux assez différents. J'ai trouvé la musique excellente mais elle ne plaira pas à tout le monde. Les seuls défauts sont pour moi la difficulté incroyable dans les derniers niveaux, surtout si vous voulez terminer tous les objectifs secondaires ; et la jouabilité, jouer uniquement avec la souris est déstabilisant mais on peut heureusement jouer avec une manette.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998118312', 'num_games_owned': 2100, 'num_reviews': 388, 'playtime_forever': 578, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 550, 'last_played': 1466205324}
review:
Rating 7.5/10
Overview: Isometric Stealth

The Good:

+ Great art style

+25 levels, each level has 2 stages

+ 3 playable character each with their own objectives and play style per level

+ The game does a good job visually presenting all dangers to you i.e enemy visions, lasers, camera etc. 

+ Each level has a ‘par time’ for replay ability

+ Great soundtrack that fits the atmosphere and art style

The Average:

If you are not interested in getting achievements, the game can be pretty short, if you are interested in achievements, the game can be pretty repetitive. 

Frustration can set in quick with this game as luck plays a big role in determining how fast and good you can complete levels. Enemy guard movement can be sporadic, its difficult to know which way they are going to go. On the one hand, it makes the game interesting and forces you to really rely on patience and timing, on the other hand, having a guard turn in the wrong direction, spotting you at the very last second just when you were about to exit the level can be rage inducing. 

Conclusion:

The Marvelous Miss Take is a fun little isometric stealth game that seems to have gone over looked in the steam community.  The premise of the game is easy enough to understand and so you can jump right into the game. It’s a fun game in short bursts. Check this game out if you are a fan of the genre.

review:
I really enjoyed my time with this game. The top down stealth style works quite well as you can get a nice look at the layout of each level and the randomized movements of the guards make you react on the fly instead of just memorizing their movement patterns and exploiting those. This leads to some moments where you will lead to some moments where you get completely screwed over but adds more tense moments to the game as you pray that guard doesn't turn around and see you. With most levels having a "par time" to beat, this makes some of your encounters intense as you need to race around and avoid detection instead of just sitting around too much. 

The level variety is good and having 3 different characters to choose from with different talents keeps the game from getting too stale. I was not overly thrilled with the enemy/obstacle variety (there are really only 4 kinds all game: guards, dogs, lasers, and security cameras) but the devs do a good job of mixing and matching those combinations in levels to keep you guessing. 

It's the stealth game you probably missed but should definitely try.

review:
The game has a good start. There's a diverse cast of characters, the art style is colourful and unique. The first few levels are fun, and adding a new thief to the mix changes things up, but things soon get repetitive. The levels are all quite similar, a new element is just added every once in a while. 

Aside from the repetitiveness, there are two main issues. The first is the controls - they use click to move and sometimes, if you don't cick the exact right spot, the pathing gets all wonky and Miss Take will run somewhere  you don't want her to go, like right into a guard. Second, the guards do not have set paths, so there's really no learning that takes place, it's just a matter of waiting them out and hoping they go in a direction that doesn't screw you over. There are abilities and items that can help you with the guards, but most have a long cooldown. 

It's interesting if you're looking for a unique stealth game with a cool cast of characters.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987572484', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 342, 'last_played': 1458294653}
review:
The Marvelous Miss Take is one of the best stealth-action game's you've probably never heard of.

You're quickly introduced to Sophia Take, the main character and find out that your Aunt had passed away and in her will she had left her art collection to Sophia. You then find out that Ralph Blackstock forges a new will and takes Sophia's Aunts entire art collection and your job is to get it back and prove he stole it from you.

Now the game is split into five chapters and each chapter is composed of five stages, to start with the stages are very basic. There are some cameras and a few guards patrolling the art gallery but as you continue they start using dogs and motion detecting lasers to try and stop you. You'll notice right away that Sophia is just your average thief, nothing too fancy; she can nimbly get away with nothing but her wits and whatever gadget the stage gave to you. As the stages get more complex you'll meet two new characters, Harry the Thief and Daisy the Pickpocket. Eventually these two characters join your party and help Sophia try and get her art collection back. Both of these characters play completely different and also have to complete seperate goals than the other two. Harry the Thief walks with a cane so he's slower than Sophia and Daisy but he can throw his trusty bouncy ball to distract guards and his missions are literal stealth missions; don't get caught at all because he can't escape easily. Daisy the Pickpocket is the fastest of the three and can walk around guards without alerting them, her missions are also drastically different; you have to steal keys from guards to open safes for cash rather than just stealing art and leaving.

This game definitely builds itself on basic but rock solid stealth mechanics - hiding, running (or walking) and stealing anything that isn't outright nailed down and then applies all of that to its extraordinary level design. On top of that the game has extremely simplistic controls, you can play it with just the mouse if you wanted to; or keyboard for movement and mouse for actions; or even just your controller. One downside is that there are no remapping controls, so if you don't have a controller and the default controls for keyboard & mouse bother you than you are out of luck.

Graphically there isn't anything to complain about, some might like the cartoony feel while others might hate it. I personally feel that it helps the game stand out amongst other games in the genre usually being dark rather than having that happy yet serious feel. Don't let the bright nature of this game fool you, it will take no mercy on you in the later stages.

Now the soundtrack for this game was phenomenal, it has that jazzy down to earth feel while you're slyly prowling around an art gallery trying your best not to get caught while you pilfer paintings or other priceless treasures.

Honestly The Marvelous Miss Take is a perfect example of how a stealth game doesn't need to be slow or tedious; how they can also be fast and lively, in a world of bright colours and memorable characters that don't need to have fifteen times the dialogue introducing them to be remembered. This game is as great as it's very own name states, it's just depressing no one really gives it the chance it deserves.

If you're into stealth games and have wondered "is this the game for me?" I can probably say without a doubt, yes it is. Highly recommend a purchase at any price; it has enough content to keep you entertained for hours and then some.

review:
Great visual presentation and music, core idea of the game is actually quite good, some semblance of a neat story going on, not half bad if you get it from a bundle (like I did), but... nah, not recommended otherwise.

Mouse-based controls are rather bad and too imprecise for what the game warrants (lost way too many times to clicking one pixel off and having the character decide that going around that wall would be a good idea, and clicking on glass domes is annoyingly imprecise). The difficulty curve isn't THAT bad, but it's just... unfun in the later stages. Depends way too much on luck; on one of the later stages, if a dog in the starting area went right instead of left, you'd lose a goddamn minute waiting for it to clear the coast, which simply isn't ok considering there are collectibles based on time limits. The pickpocket's levels pretty much force you to cause alerts over and over again, defeating the whole purpose of going stealthy.

Frankly, it all kinda sounds like nitpicking, but I simply didn't have fun with this and can't recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198149941288', 'num_games_owned': 930, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 391, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 391, 'last_played': 1454398207}
review:
The Marvellous Miss Take是一款2D俯视视角潜行盗窃游戏，名字中的Miss Take谐音mistake很有意思，女主人公名叫Take代表拿（偷），又代表这种行为是一种错误，然而无论怎么翻译都没有这种韵味，索性我就把它翻译成“妙手空空小姐”。

       玩家扮演的角色Sophia Take的姑妈是一位收藏家，秉持艺术品应该属于免费美术馆的理念，而黑心商人Ralph Blackstock想买她的收藏品却被拒绝，姑妈去世后理应由她最后一位亲人我们的Miss Sophia Take来继承，可是Ralph Blackstock 却伪造了一封遗嘱，将所有藏品都转移到了他的名下。Miss Take不愿意让坏人继续得意下去，决定用她自己的方式夺回属于她属于大家的艺术品。

      游戏流程不长， 游戏模式也比较简单，并没有通过过关获得的奖励来升级人物或者道具等成长元素，这一点可能让一部分人会失去玩下去的动力，我就单纯当做休闲的小游戏来玩，也避免了需要反复刷刷刷的情况。

      虽然是一款潜入游戏，游戏的画面设计却非常讨巧，简单而又可爱的卡通风格色彩鲜明，凸显轻松的风格，优雅的艺术品女大盗，踏着自己的步伐把一件件艺术品全部收回。游戏的BGM也充满了轻松的氛围，当收集到艺术品的时候刷刷刷的音效也让我听着很爽。
体来说这个游戏在休闲游戏中属于优秀的作品，原本就是为了让人轻松休闲的游戏确实能让人感到放松和愉悦。有一个有意思的细节，在家里切换人物的时候会产生很多有意思的对话可以让我们更多地了解人物，细心的玩家可以去收集一下哈哈哈。

      [u]最后最重要的一点是，这就应该是一个移动端游戏啊[/u]。我刚开始玩不久就觉得这个游戏很适合出在手机啊ipad啊上玩，从简单的操作到这种卡通的风格，做成手机游戏一定很有人气哈哈哈（以国内手游的套路还可以加入道具圈钱哈哈哈），不知道Rising Star有没有考虑过这件事情呢。
吐槽一句：开头的标题画面好像绿箭口香糖的标志啊有没有，如果你一直停在开头还可以看到有一只手会和这个标题互动。

author: {'steamid': '76561198003970062', 'num_games_owned': 2038, 'num_reviews': 355, 'playtime_forever': 733, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 733, 'last_played': 1452750736}
review:
The Marvelous Miss Take is a stylish stealth game which focuses on distraction and dealing with randomly wandering guards as its primary mechanics.

The game stars the Sophia Take, an heiress whose aunt’s fortune (and more importantly, her art) is all stolen (via a forged will) by Ralph, an evil megalomaniac whose focus seems to be hoarding the art for himself rather than sharing it with THE PEOPLE. Sophia’s goal is to steal all the art back and expose Ralph for what he is.

Joining her on her quest are Harry, an older thief with a bum leg, and Daisy, a young, seemingly orphaned pickpocket who joins the team.

The game’s stealth gameplay is very simple – click to walk to a location, hold down the mouse button to run there, and use the right mouse button to throw a device (which varies by character and level) to distract or get around the guards. Ducking behind obstacles is automatic as long as you aren’t running, and the fields of view of all the guards are displayed via very simple and easy-to-understand visual displays.

The levels are all viewed from a top-down isometric perspective which is pretty heavily constrained around your character, meaning you’re exploring the level as you’re penetrating it. What makes this game unusual for a stealth game is that, contrary to most such games, the guards – both in the form of men and dogs – wander randomly through the level, meaning that you cannot rely on them to turn just the right direction or walk just the right way. This also means that waiting around can get you trapped between randomly wandering guards, so it pays to move quickly and to distract the guards to get them to go where you want them to go, either by showing yourself to them, making some noise, or by throwing a noise-making gadget.

Sophia’s goal in each level is to collect all the golden art pieces, set up on walls and pedestals, and then make it to the elevator or exit. Every level has two independent floors to it, and if you fail on the second floor, you start over at the start of that floor, not at the start of the level. On top of that primary goal, she has two secondary goals – she can break the glass around a special statue which appears once per floor, which attracts the attention of the nearest guard, or she can try and do a speed run through the level, completing it within a certain amount of time. In most of the levels, Sophia finds an item lying on a pedestal near the entrance that helps her clear the level – a noise-maker that can be thrown to distract guards, glue to stick them in place, a smoke bomb to obstruct their view, or a teleporter to skip past them.

If Sophia is spotted by the guards, she has to go hide before they catch her; if they catch her, you must start the floor over. Unfortunately, even if you are not captured, Sophia will drop her (very stylish) hat, which must be retrieved before she can complete the level.

Her two allies have slightly different gameplay. Harry always has the same item – a noise-making ball which bounces off the walls – wherever he goes, but as it is his lucky charm, he must collect it back up before completing a level. His missions take place at night in the same rooms that Miss Take’s missions take place in, but with a different setup of guards, and various barriers put in place to obstruct his route through the level. Unlike Sophia, he can’t run, but on the upside, he only has to collect three paintings per floor. His alternate goal is to make it through levels without being spotted by any guards or cameras.

Daisy has no special items at all to help her, but on the upside, she can walk right up behind guards without alerting them, and is the fastest character in the game. Like Harry, she plays in the same stages Sophia does, but with barriers up (though different ones than Harry, oftentimes), and with different guard setups. Daisy must pickpocket keys off the guards to unlock safes and retrieve deeds. The safes are alarmed, so Daisy must run away quickly after avoiding a safe to avoid getting caught. Her levels tend to be the most frustrating simply because the guards must be approached up close, and the safes always create intense situations. Like Sophia, her goal is to speed-run through every level, which is the hardest goal in the game due to the random movements of the guards, and can sometimes lead to extreme frustration.

Indeed, the game’s greatest flaw is its randomized nature. At times, the enemies will turn around and completely screw up your quickly thrown-together plan, and there are occaisions where you will simply be forced to reset a stage because guards randomly wander in through both ends of a hallway. Such events are sometimes your fault, but at other times, the random nature of the game can be quite annoying – especially when doing speed-runs as Daisy, who is pretty dependent on a good guard setup at times to complete her run in time.

The game’s other flaw is its repetitive nature. There are 25 stages, and all but one of them is played through by all three characters, leaving a total of 73 stages in all. However, there are very few mechanics in the game. There are the basic guards who wander around and are the only thing which can actually catch your character. There are security cameras which move automatically back and forth over a field of space, but which have blind spots which can be taken advantage of to sneak around; if you move into their field of view, they will alert the guards to your presence. There are dogs, who will sniff out your character if you are close to them, but which have a very restricted field of view; these canines will at time track you throughout the level if you don’t throw out something to distract them, and can at times feel very frustrating as they home in on you. If the dog catches you, it will bark at you, alerting the guards. Finally, there are lasers which periodically turn off and on, which set off an alarm alerting the guards if you stand on them.

That’s all there is, and it really shows, as the games’ levels don’t really exhibit much variety. Once the mechanics have all been introduced, you’ve seen all the game really has to offer, and the final levels are hard simply because they throw a large number of things at you all at once. While they’re interesting enough, they’re also the place where the random movements of the enemies are the most frustrating, as the large numbers of enemies populating many of those levels means there is more opportunity for you to get cornered. Thus, the game varies from kind of samey to kind of frustrating, and Sophia’s levels are by far the most enjoyable, as it is the first time through a set-up and her broader skill-set and larger number of objectives just feel like they flow better.

Overall, the game is pretty mediocre. The story is flimsy and not particularly interesting. The art style is quite nice – very deco – but isn’t enough to carry the game on its own, and while the core stealth gameplay is alright, it also starts to feel the same after a while.

Ultimately, this is a game best eaten in small bites – none of the levels are very long, with speed run times of four minutes or less which are readily achievable, and completing everything the game has to offer is likely to take only 12 hours or so. When the odd level is played here and there, it doesn’t wear on you so much, but when a lot are played consecutively, it tends to get kind of boring (or frustrating).

Really, though, I wouldn’t recommend it - it isn't a very substantive experience. While the game encouraging you to move quickly and distract foes actually gets rid of one of the worst parts about stealth games – boringly waiting around for a guard to walk by on the right portion of its pattern – it replaces it with the frustration of the RNG occasionally spoiling your run.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993008418', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 140, 'last_played': 1451470792}
review:
The Marvelous Miss Take is essentially a stealth game stripped down to its core elements, with a top down camera, vision cones reminiscent of early Metal Gear Solid games, and the slight flavouring of a puzzle game on top. This is wrapped up in a slick presentation, which is sadly the game's greatest strength.

Sophia moves at a fairly slow pace and will automatically crouch behind waist-high objects--it's better to think of any waist-high objects as walls, since they effectively block vision cones in a similar way, though also preventing Sophia from running. Running produces a noise radius that alerts guards to your location, so it must be done outside of a certain distance from a guard. Additionally, Sophia occasionally collects gadgets, and can earn additional uses for these gadgets by looting art. This is a fairly smart system that rewards skilful play.

The problem, then, is the game's randomized AI. Randomized AI does not work very well for a game with light puzzle elements and time trials. Guards move in random directions, sometimes leaving the rooms they are stationed in. This randomized AI can put you in very unfavourable situations, sometimes (if you are extremely unlucky) as soon as the level starts. Often, they can put you in unwinnable positions even after collecting all the trophies, or waste a lot of your time. Completing heists can require several attempts to get lucky. Getting under par time also happens because you were lucky; the AI didn't put you in any strange situations, or you restarted each floor until you beat it with time to spare.

Dogs suck up all the fun with their presence. Their scent radius is huge and they will follow your trail around the entire map if you let them, putting you in unwinnable situations that force a restart. Dogs are very often placed in rooms with security cameras, which further reduces your mobility options and makes dogs a nightmare to deal with.

Miss Take isn't a very good stealth game. There are much better stealth games out there. Miss Take doesn't innovate, and it doesn't even iterate, either. It doesn't really have anything new to offer to the genre. Its presentation is its only redeeming quality. Get it on sale, if you're curious.

review:
만화풍의 아기자기한 그래픽이 돋보이는 잠입액션 게임이다. 캐릭터는 3명이 있으며 각각 플레이 스타일이 다르다. 같은 맵을 3명이 다른 식으로 클리어하는 재미가 있다. 단순히 사각지대에서 은밀하게 움직이는 것뿐 아니라 잠입을 도와주는 각종 도구를 사용하기도 한다.

주인공을 방해하는 경비나 개는 어느 정도 랜덤하게 움직이기 때문에 무작정 패턴을 외울 수는 없고 그때그때의 임기응변이 필요하다. 운에 맡기고 무작정 뛰어다니는 게 의외의 결과를 낳기도 한다. 들키더라도 구석진 데에 숨어 기회를 노릴 수도 있다. 맵 곳곳의 미술품을 모아서 출구로 나가면 끝이지만 스테이지마다 캐릭터별 도전과제가 있다. (타임어택, 안들키기 등) 스테이지 디자인이 다채롭지 못한 건 단점

이런 류의 게임이 보통 그렇듯, 스테이지가 높아지면서 점점 짜증나는 상황이 많아진다. 도전과제 신경 안쓰고 클리어 목표로 한다면 그럭저럭 할만하다. 별거 없는 스토리지만 캐릭터별로 깔끔하게 끝난다. 잠입액션 취향이면 강추. 잡식성 게이머에겐 할인가로 추천

author: {'steamid': '76561198125664030', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 381, 'playtime_forever': 913, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 913, 'last_played': 1527229617}
review:
通关撒花：奇妙的塔凯小姐，一款潜行类游戏。

全作共5章，每章5关，每关分为两部分。随着游戏发展，会解锁两个新人物，一个擅长在夜间偷名画，另外一个则是盗取钥匙的小偷，开启新章节的必要条件是三个人都偷一定数量的东西。

如果非常喜欢这款游戏的话，可以用三个人物分别通关，过程不尽相同，可玩度很高。

障碍主要有警卫、狗、摄像头、红外线几种，后期的关卡是几种障碍结合起来。红外线和摄像头绝对不能碰，警报范围太大，很难逃脱。被狗发现，狗会狂吠，一直到警卫赶来为止，但是可以甩掉。被警卫发现之后，如果动作够迅速，躲到他看不见的地方可以化险为夷，相当刺激。死角很多，注意自己的位置一定要在阴影处，以地板上显示的为准。必要时可发出声音将警卫或者狗引开再行动，跑步会发出声音，注意范围提示。

有时候会给一些道具，胶水、留声机、烟雾弹等等，但是不算很实用，不借助道具一样可以过关。主角专属道具是不能丢的，过关之前一定要捡回来，比如主角苏菲小姐的帽子。

收集到所有需要盗取的珍宝，才能过关，那一刻的成就感无与伦比，推荐入手。

author: {'steamid': '76561198023672465', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 170, 'last_played': 1448678233}
review:
Pros/Cons

+ Snazzy jazzy soundtrack
+ Simple clean visuals
+ Daisy’s heists are generally quite fun
+ Open solutions, levels can be cleared in different ways using different paths
+ Lots of optional levels

- Levels all look and sound the same, repetitve
- Most optional levels are just reskins of campaign levels
- Very standard stealth gameplay, nothing really stands out or feels new
- Character abilities are very limited
- Successfully completing a heist often feels like the result of chance rather than skill, leading to frustration
- This chance leads to frequent failure, meaning having to replay missions again and again
- Harry’s missions are tedious and dull

I wanted to like The Marvelous Miss Take. I love stealth games, it had an awesome upbeat jazzy soundtrack, cool visual style, minimalist gameplay that’s quick to get into and quick to complete, and as cardboard cutout and cartoony as they were, I liked the characters. But the more I played the more I had to admit to myself that I just wasn’t enjoying the game. It’s a bizarre mix of frustrating and boring.

What I enjoy best about stealth games is two things. The first is the patient methodical observing and memorizing of guard movements and behaviors, exploring and finding the best paths to the goal, the trial and error of taking a risk, getting caught, revising strategies, and trying again until I get it right. I love the feeling of having finally outwitted, out snuck, outrun every guard by the end of the level, the feeling of having conquered using wits instead of brawn. The second is gadgets. The stealth genre is great at giving players all sorts of toys to play around with--noisemakers, sleep gas, night vision, zip lines, disguises, hacking systems, teleportation, invisibility.

Marvelous Miss Take is a stealth game. The goal of each ‘heist’ is to sneak through an art gallery, avoiding guards, cameras, and trip wires in order to steal and escape with various pieces of artwork. Levels are very small, consisting of only a few rooms, two floors, and a handful of guards. Most can be beaten in just a couple of minutes. 

The thing is, the guards don’t follow any set paths, more or less randomly wandering about the level. On the one hand, this is cool, because it leads to every playthrough of a level going a bit differently. There is an unpredictability to guard movements that’ll keep you on edge the whole time, as no area is safe. They can find you anywhere. Unfortunately, this also leads to frustration. Finishing a level is almost always dependent on luck. At the end of a heist, I almost never felt like I’d expertly outwitted a group of guards, because beating levels depends on things as trite as Guard 2 just happening to not patrol the room full of trip wires this go around, or maybe because one of the guard dogs happened to get stuck in a corner.

All the other times you fail often have less to do with mistakes you make and more to do with getting unlucky with where the guards decided to wander. The player doesn’t have many options for escaping when cornered. Besides a few limited use noise makers and smoke bombs, Sophia, the main character, has nothing in the way of cool gadgets for players to play with (with the exception of a teleporter that unfortunately only appears in a couple levels), and most levels don’t even have those. Difficulty ramps up pretty quick, and you’re going to fail heists, and you’re going to fail them over and over. Levels are very short, so you won’t end up replaying much. But when every level has the exact same visuals, guards, dogs, cameras, and goals, the game is repetitive enough already. Everything is very expected, all as per genre. You won’t find anything new here.

The developers do try to inject some variety into the gameplay with two other playable characters. Both are able to replay heists already completed with Sophia, but with some added challenges and abilities. The first is Harry, who is much slower than Sophia and has nothing to show for it except a noisemaker that is made useless because it has to be picked up after thrown. With Harry, you’ll be playing through the exact same level as with Sophia, stealing the same sort of artwork, except more slowly. It’s beyond tedious. 

The third playable character is Daisy, whose heists are easily the highlight of the game. Daisy is both faster and quieter than Sophia. Her heists strip down most of the extra fat in randomly wandering guards and dogs from Sophia’s missions, and instead involve her pickpocketing just two or three guards, and then using the keys to open alarm-rigged safes. I had a great time sneaking directly behind and beside guards to get their keys, and using strategy to draw them away from safes long enough to get in and out before the safe alarm sent the guards charging back to my position. It’s a shame her missions are so much shorter than Harry or Sophia’s. It’s the only time I felt like a professional cat burglar while playing.

At the end of the day, I’m not sure who this game is for. It has a cool style and soundtrack, the minimalism and bite-sized levels makes it easy to jump in and out of. But it has none of the things I usually look for in a stealth game. I expect casual players will be put off by the frustrating chance-laden levels, but I also expect fans of the genre will be disappointed by how limited the stealth gameplay is. And twenty dollars is an awfully steep asking price for the amount of content you’re getting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198165236215', 'num_games_owned': 8496, 'num_reviews': 275, 'playtime_forever': 259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1462840860}
review:
专注发行各种女主游戏的长Rising Star的又一部作品，最开始吸引我注意的就是这款游戏奇妙的名字——The Marvellous Miss Take，Mistake和Miss Take的谐音让游戏的两大核心元素一目了然：女主、潜行（偷窃）。关于游戏的中文译名之前也是没有的，我私下粗粗起了一个“惊奇女大盗”，感觉画风还是不对就没管了，后来开始有人翻译成“奇妙的塔凯小姐”，完全丧失的原本游戏名字的特色……但是也许结合一下，叫“奇妙女大盗”也许就比较接近了。

在这款游戏中，主角Miss Take要去各个艺术品展馆中偷取藏品，玩家需要操控这名窈窕淑女避开所有警卫和摄像头的视线取得宝物，然后潇洒离开。随着游戏的展开，艺术馆会出现更多的楼层，玩家还可以使用录音带等道具来引开警卫的视线，就算什么道具都不用，技艺精湛的Take也可以靠娴熟的口哨和小碎步来扰乱警卫的注意力。游戏为典型的俯视视角潜行游戏玩法，关卡式的设计辅以精美立体又充满女性美得画风和轻松活泼的BGM，使得The Marvellous Miss Take更侧重其休闲性。闲暇好时光，偷几幅名画来装点自己的小屋吧~

+精致又丰富的潜行关卡设计
+完成得十分漂亮的画面，从人物到建筑都很精美，是一大加分项
+尽管女主角Miss Take没有配音，但她的角色形象仍然十分饱满，而且充满了电影中时尚、俏丽又潇洒的女性美，角色塑造得很有魅力
+BGM轻松又俏皮，跟游戏的风格很契合

-没有升级系统，注定了它只能在众多潜行游戏中追求休闲性，却缺少了一些刺激，无法解决潜行游戏玩法比较单一且需要耐心所带来的负面影响。所以，游戏跟它68元人民币的原价肯定是不匹配的，但是半价左右就差不多了。
